title: Symptomatic Hyperthyroidism Requiring Surgery
diagnosis_topic: Graves disease refractory to medical therapy
setup_script: A 30-year-old woman with Graves disease presents with palpitations, weight loss, and ophthalmopathy despite high doses of methimazole and beta-blockers. She desires definitive therapy and is considering thyroidectomy versus radioactive iodine.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Review symptoms of thyrotoxicosis and confirm diagnosis with suppressed TSH and elevated free T4/T3.
Assess for contraindications to radioactive iodine (e.g., pregnancy, ophthalmopathy) and discuss pros/cons of each treatment.
Explain surgical indications: large goiter, suspicion for cancer, patient preference, or failed medical management.
Order preoperative evaluation including CBC, CMP, thyroid antibody levels, and laryngoscopy for vocal cord function.
Ensure patient is euthyroid preoperatively using beta-blockers and possibly iodine or potassium iodide to reduce vascularity.
Discuss need for total thyroidectomy and potential complications (hypocalcemia, RLN injury, bleeding).
Plan intraoperative management including nerve monitoring and parathyroid identification.
Perform total thyroidectomy; note presence of vascular goiter requiring careful dissection.
Postoperative management: monitor airway, drain output, serum calcium; start levothyroxine replacement.
Evaluate pathology report; confirm absence of malignancy and completeness of excision.
Arrange endocrinology follow-up for long-term hormone replacement and adjust dosing.
Educate patient on recognition of hypocalcemia symptoms and need for lifelong follow-up.

critical_decision_points: Ensuring patient is euthyroid before surgery to avoid thyroid storm.
Discussing definitive treatment options and respecting patient preference.
Safe dissection with identification and preservation of recurrent laryngeal nerves and parathyroid glands.
Immediate postoperative monitoring of airway and calcium levels.
Appropriate endocrinology referral for lifelong hormone management.
